page.title: 16Conservation
page.content: the Woodland Trust bought Pepper Wood in 1981. It cost Â£50000.New paths were cleared in 1982 to create a circular walk. Some volunteers helped to make a small pond. In Medieval times people dug ditches to keep animals out of Pepper Wood; you can still see part of the bank and ditch today. Coppicing and thinning work which volunteers are carrying out creates a large supply of wood. This is being converted into useful products which are being sold for use in the local community.Products include bean poles, tree stakes, fence posts, rustic fencing, hedging stakes, clothes line props, tent pegs, besoms and fire wood.
